repnme.cdata!:
Cote d'Ivoire - Human Resources
            Development Management Support Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Human Resources
            Development Management Support Project for Cote
            d'Ivoire was satisfactory. The project achieved its
            objectives, its impact on institutional development was
            substantial, sustainability is likely, and the performance
            of both the Bank and Borrower was satisfactory. Several
            lessons can be learned from this project. First, project
            design must take into account the presence of qualified
            personnel in the civil service who only need to undertake
            training in order to update their skills. Second, the fact
            that the TA was not permanent led to a real transfer of
            knowledge throughout the project's life. Third, there
            was a clear understanding with the Borrower that expert
            intervention would only take place upon completion of
            specific tasks and sanctions would be made if these tasks
            were not completed as agreed. Fourth, flexibility on the
            part of the Bank aided in the project's success and
            consistent actions have been retained in future operations.
            Finally, future operations can build upon the TA experience
            gained through this project, thereby allowing for a
            consistent Bank strategy in the sector.

18153061.theme: Education for the knowledge economy,Education for all,Social analysis and monitoring,Administrative and civil service reform

repnme.cdata!:
Cote d'Ivoire - Human Resources
            Management Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Human Resources Development
            Management Support Project is designed to improve the
            capacity of Cote d'Ivoire's human resource
            ministries to implement operational strategies by raising
            the level of ministry staff skills in key areas.  The
            project will provide funds for incremental short- and
            medium-term technical assistance and training, and for a
            complement of new equipment to assist the human resource
            ministries in establishing adequate systems for:  (a)
            planning, programming and budgeting; and (b) monitoring and
            evaluation of service delivery performance and the impact of
            policies and programs, including beneficiary assessments.
            In addition, the project will assist the Ministry of
            National Education to launch a quality schools initiative
            with the aim of promoting improvements in the quality of
            learning and management performance of schools.  Lastly,
            operational support will be provided for the Operations
            Committee to permit it to monitor the transfer of
            technology, which is the basis of the project, and to
            conduct policy-driven pre-investment studies for the human
            resources sectors.
